'''José Erasmo Janer Gironella''' (1833-1911) was a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] entrepreneur and politician. As a businessman he is considered a member of the textile-industry-related [[Catalonia|Catalan]] [[bourgeoisie]], which enjoyed peak of its power in the mid-19th century; Janer represented this group during its declining phase. Politically he earned his name as a [[Carlist]] and headed the Catalan branch of the party between 1902 and 1910.
==Family and youth== [[File:Casa Erasme de Gònima 2.jpg|thumb|left|[[:ca:Casa Erasme de Gònima|Ca l'Erasme]], Barcelona]] Some scholars consider the Janer family past an illustration of [[social history]] in Catalonia, its rise and decline demonstrating patterns of change within the local ruling strata.<ref>the author who studied family patterns among the Catalan wealthy notes that a group of families – including the Gónimas and the Janers – took advantage of social mobility opportunities of the late 18th century and emerged as new bourgeoisie related to the textile industry; "in the 19th century this extremely tight kindred moved their wealth into land and other status markers. They held political power through the Junta de Comerc and the municipal administration. Yet in the next generations their situation and circumstances changed radically"; according to the author, the endogamous marriage pattern first contributed to the rise, and then to the fall of the Gónima-Janer and other merchant families, Gary Wray McDonogh, ''Good Families of Barcelona: A Social History of Power in the Industrial Era'', Princeton 2014, {{ISBN|9781400858231}}, see esp. pages 148, 159 and 161</ref> Erasmo's paternal grandfather [[Domingo Janer Sunyer]] (1762-1807) was son to a provincial doctor<ref>Domingo Janer Sunyer's father – his name not referred – originated from Igualada, Anna Vallugera Fuster, ''El mercat artístic a Barcelona (1770-1808). Producció, consum i comerç d'art'' [PhD thesis Universidad de Barcelona], Barcelona 2015, p. 875, also Reis Fontanals, ''Erasme de Gònima, l'Oberkampf català'', [in:] ''Barcelona Quaderns d'História'' 17 (2011), p. 222</ref> and commenced his career as a petty merchant from [[Esparreguera]];<ref>Rosa Creixell, Teresa-María Sala, ''Retrat de família: els secrets dels Gónima'', [in:] ''Barcelona Quaferns d'Historia'' 12 (2005), p. 182</ref> rising to prosperity, he was [[Ennoblement|ennobled]] in 1795.<ref>see the graph in Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 160</ref> He married heiress<ref>named Josefa Gónima Coll (1767-1802), Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 160</ref> to an emergent Gónima textile fortune;<ref>the Gónima industrial empire was founded by her father Erasme de Gónima (1746-1827), who "exemplified the rapid social mobility possible for late 18-th century industrialists in Barcelona. Born a weaver in provincial Catalonia, by his death he was a noble", Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 158. He is considered one of the greatest textile industrialists of his time and compared to a French-Swiss tycoon, [[Christophe-Philippe Oberkampf]], see Fontanals 2011</ref> both died prematurely. Their only son and the future father of Erasmo, [[:ca:Erasme de Janer i de Gònima|Erasmo Janer Gónima]] (1791-1862), inherited the hugely successful business in 1821; at that time it was crowned with the largest European [[Textile manufacturing|textile factory]] which employed some 1,200 workers.<ref>Fontanals 2011, p. 235</ref> Himself representative of a new strata of commerce and industry tycoons which started to surpass landed aristocracy and old urban bourgeoisie,<ref>"his descendants, however, did not enter the economic and social world of either the old landed aristocracy or the new bourgeoisie. The result was an endogamous group "between" the other two categories. Elite social marginality reflected economic change within a new milieu". Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 158</ref> in the mid-19th century Janer Gónima brought the family to business and political climax. Member of executive boards of countless economic organizations,<ref>Janer Gónima was e.g. in the first Junta of Societat Econòmica d'Amics del País (1822), the first Junta of l'Institut Agrícola Català de Sant Isidre (1851), in the executive board of Comisió de Fábriques, in Junta de Comerç and numerous other bodies. He was also director of Teatre Principal in Barcelona, Fontanals 2011, pp. 233 and passim, ''Erasme de Janer i de Gónima'' entry, [in:] ''Gran Enciclopédia Catalana'' online, available [https://www.enciclopedia.cat/EC-GEC-0034318.xml here]</ref> he held key positions in municipal administration, served as [[alcalde]] of [[Barcelona]] in 1846 and as a provincial deputy in the 1850s.<ref>Janer Gónima served in Junta Superior Gubernativa de Barcelona in 1835, as mayor of the city during a few months in 1846, as a Moderate Party deputy to Corts de Barcelona in two strings of 1852-1854 and 1856-1858, Ramon Arnabat Mata, ''Revolució i contrarevolució a Catalunya durant el trienni liberal (1820-1823)'' [PhD thesis Universitat Pompeu Fabra], Barcelona 1999, p. 202</ref> In the mid-19th century he shut down the textile factory<ref>Janer Gónima he sold the textile manufacturing business to Salvador Juncadella in 1856, Jaume Artigues i Vidal, ''Les fàbriques d'indianes com a model d'espai fabril'', [in:] ''Barcelona Quaderns d'Historia'' 17 (2011), p. 273</ref> and re-focused the family business on finance,<ref>Janer Gónima was among co-founders of a few insurance and re-insurance companies, especially Caja de Ahorros y Monte de Piedad de Barcelona</ref> railways<ref>e.g. he engaged in construction of the first railway lines from Barcelona, first to Mataró and then to Tarragona, Creixel, Sala 2005, p. 189</ref> and commerce.<ref>''Fons Gónima-Janer. Ariu Biblioteca de Catalunya'' [information leaflet], Barcelona 2011, p. 2</ref>
In 1813 Janer Gónima married Josefa Gironella Ayguals, daughter to another Barcelona textile industry tycoon.<ref>Josefa Gironella Ayguals was daughter to fabricant d'indianes Josep Gironella and granddaughter to Cristóbal de Gironella Pujols, the founder of the dynasty. He was member of the register of commerce, director of Junta de Comerc and a "ciutadá honrat" of Barcelona after 1780; the family was ennobled in 1780, Wray McDonogh 2014, pp. 159-160. For a review of the Gironella family rise to power see ''La finca de Gironella'', [in:] ''Historia Sarria'' service, available [http://www.historiadesarria.com/gironella.htm here]</ref> The couple had 5<ref>see the genealogical tree in Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 160</ref> or 7<ref>see the genealogical tree in ''Janer Gironella'' entry, [in:] ''Geneanet'' service, available [https://gw.geneanet.org/sanchiz?lang=en&p=ignacia&n=janer+gironella here]</ref> children; out of two sons, it was José Erasmo who became heir to the family wealth.<ref>José Erasme Janer Gironella is referred as "heir in the fourth generation" to the Gónima/Janer fortune, Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 159. It is not clear what happened to his brother Erasme. In one genealogical chart Erasme appears to be the oldest of the siblings, Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 160, yet it is not clear whether he died in early infancy, entered a religious order or for any other reason did not inherit the family fortune</ref> At unspecified time though probably in the 1840s he frequented the [[Piarist]] college of St. Anthony in Barcelona,<ref>''Josep Erasme de Janer i Gironella'' entry, [in:] ''Escola Pia Sant Antoni'' service, available [http://santantoni200.escolapia.cat/josep-erasme-de-janer-i-gironella-1833-1911/ here]</ref> to complete education while studying law at [[University of Barcelona|Universidad de Barcelona]] and graduating most likely in the mid-1850s.<ref>''La Defensa'' 19.03.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1095519&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Gradually getting engaged in running the family business, in 1864 José Erasmo married Dolores Milá de la Roca Vilaseca;<ref>Dolores Milá de la Roca died in 1910, her birth date is not known, ''El Correo Español'' 30.07.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029789041&page=2 here]</ref> her family, also ennobled merchants, became landowners rather than engaged in potentially profitable but risky urban ventures.<ref>Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 159</ref> Basking in inherited opulence the couple settled in the Janer family residence in Barcelona, in the iconic building known as [[:ca:Casa Erasme de Gònima|Ca l'Erasme]].<ref>''Josep Erasme de Janer i Gironella'' entry, [in:] ''Escola Pia Sant Antoni'' service, available [http://santantoni200.escolapia.cat/josep-erasme-de-janer-i-gironella-1833-1911/ here]; the iconic Ca l'Erasme is considered one of two best examples of Catalan bourgeoisie architecture, Sílvia Canalda i Llobet, Carme Narváez Cases, Joan Sureda, ''Cartografías visuales y arquitectónicas de la modernidad: Siglos XV-XVIII'', Barcelona 2011, {{ISBN|9788447535408}}, p. 123. Ca l'Erasme was refurbished and decorated with new works of art to celebrate the 1864 marriage of José Erasme; he sold the mansion half a century later</ref> [[File:Ramon Casas - MNAC- Ignasi Janer- 027603-D 006593.jpg|thumb|160px|[[:ca:Ignasi de Janer i Milà de la Roca|Ignacio Janer Milà]]]] José Erasmo and Dolores had 7 children, though only two of them married: the second oldest son<ref>the oldest son Erasme Janer Milá de la Roca (1866-1886) entered the Jesuit order and died prematurely</ref> and the family heir [[:ca:Ignasi de Janer i Milà de la Roca|Ignacio Janer Milá de la Roca]] became a locally known historian and writer,<ref>the second-oldest son Ignacio Janer Milá de la Roca (1869-1919) in 1894 married Soledad de Durán de Brichfeus, descendant of two lines of the minor nobility. Her father, although the mayer of Barcelona, had sold off much of the family property. Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 159</ref> while Mercedes wed a Carlist politician [[Dalmacio Iglesias García|Dalmacio Iglesias]]. Another daughter María de los Angeles became a Carlist propagandist.<ref>Mercedes Janer Milá de la Roca (1864-1945) was the oldest of the siblings. For a homage information see ''Janer y Milá de la Roca (María de los Angeles de)'', [in:] ''Tradición Viva'' service, available [http://www.tradicionviva.es/2015/10/05/janer-y-mila-de-la-roca-maria-de-los-angeles-de/ here]. In 1936 she was nominated head of the Carlist feminine organization in Catalonia, Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El Carlisme Català Durant La Segona República Espanyola 1931-1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|8478260803}}, 9788478260805, p. 261</ref> José Erasmo and Dolores had 5 grandchildren;<ref>four – Erasme, Enrique, María de las Mercedes and María de los Dolores Janer Durán - were the children of Ignacio Janer Milá de la Roca and Soledad Durán; one – María de las Mercedes Iglesias Janer - was the daughter of Mercedes Janer Milá de la Roca and Dalmacio Iglesias, for her marriage see ''La Vanguardia'' 19.10.35, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/04/05/pagina-8/33145356/pdf.html here]</ref> both grandsons were youth Carlist activists during the [[Second Spanish Republic|Second Republic]] years<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.07.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000549663&page=21 here]</ref> and [[Requetés|requeté volunteers]]<ref>for Erasmo see e.g. ''In Memoriam Montjuich 1936'', [in:] ''Requetés'' service, available [http://www.requetes.com/julio.html here]. For Enrique see e.g. Aram Monfort i Coll, ''La depuració franquista dels advocats de Barcelona (1939–1945). Una aproximació a l'Iŀustre Coŀegi d'Advocats de Barcelona de la postguerra'', [in:] ''Franquisme & Transició'' 1 (2013), p. 139</ref> during the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]]. The older one, Erasmo Janer Duran, was executed by the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republicans]];<ref>César Alcalá, ''La represión política en Cataluña (1936-1939)'', Madrid 2005, {{ISBN|8496281310}}, p. 129</ref> the younger one, Enrique Janer Duran,<ref>Enrique Janer Durán (birth data unknown, died 1990) in 1927 married Concha de la Llave y Valarino (died 1971), ''La Vanguardia'' 08.05.27, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1899/06/25/pagina-11/33246292/pdf.html here]</ref> survived the war to become a lawyer;<ref>as lawyer and municipal official Enrique Janer Duran served as treasurer of the post-war Junta de Abogados in Barcelona and was involved in expropriation of possessions of the executed [[Manuel Carrasco Formiguera|Carrasco y Formiguera]], ''La Vanguardia'' 28.05.95, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1986/06/12/pagina-3/33781435/pdf.htm here] l</ref> since the early 1940s till the late 1970s he held various mid-range positions in the Barcelona city council,<ref>he first entered Comisión Gestora, as during early Francoism municipal governing bodies were appointed and not elected, see ''Los hombres del nuevo poder'', [in:] ''Barcelona en posguerra'' service, available [http://www.bcn.cat/bcnpostguerra/exposiciovirtual/es/2.1-el-nuevo-poder.html here]</ref> from secretary of the ayuntamiento<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 18.06.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1935/06/02/pagina-5/33116969/pdf.html here]</ref> to teniente auditor,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 01.07.39, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1939/07/01/pagina-2/33117610/pdf.html here]</ref> jefé de sección<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 14.07.57, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1957/06/06/pagina-27/32760303/pdf.html here]</ref> and head of the transport department.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 22.04.72, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1971/09/15/pagina-9/34294237/pdf.html here], for transición period see also ''La Vanguardia'' 27.05.78, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1978/05/27/pagina-33/33728990/pdf.html here]; in 1974 he was rewarded for the longtime service, ''La Vanguardia'' 31.12.74, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1971/09/15/pagina-23/34236791/pdf.html here]</ref> As neither Erasmo nor Enrique had sons,<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 25.07.71, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1970/03/18/pagina-29/33603249/pdf.html here]</ref> the Janer line has extinguished. The nephews of José Erasmo, [[:ca:Josep Maria de Lasarte i de Janer|José María]] and [[:ca:Erasme de Lasarte i de Janer|Erasme Lasarte Janer]], became known in local Catalan realm respectively as a writer and as a painter.
==Conservative to Carlist (1864-1876)== [[File:Federico Madrazo - Retrato de Juan de la Pezuela.jpg|thumb|180px|left|[[:es:Juan de la Pezuela|Juan de la Pezuela]]]] As heir to the former mayor of Barcelona and son to one of the most potent men in the city Janer was destined to become a public figure, yet political preferences of his ancestors are not entirely clear. Historians note that as tycoons of new bourgeoisie the Janers and the Gónimas were [[Liberalism in Spain|Liberals]],<ref>one author claims that Liberalism was naturally the option embraced by a new breed of Catalan industrialists, including the ancestors of Janer Gironella, Wray McDonogh 2014, pp. 148, 161</ref> while the Gironellas were even related to the revolutionary [[Progressive Party (Spain)|exaltado]] version of Spanish liberalism.<ref>the maternal uncle, Antonio Gironella Ayguals, was a revolutionary Exaltado at one point deported to the Canary Islands; he was the co-founder of a masonic lodge, see ''La finca de Gironella'', [in:] ''Historia Sarria'' service, available [http://www.historiadesarria.com/gironella.htm here]</ref> One source claims that during the [[First Carlist War]] his father joined the liberal Barcelona juntas<ref>Manuel Santirso Rodríguez, ''Gerifaltes de antanó. Los señores catalanes en el primer carlismo'', [in:] ''Militars. Espai i História'' XXIII (2000), p. 152</ref> while another one states that in the mid-1840s he was a [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]],<ref>Creixell, Sala 2005, p. 189</ref> which might point to not an unusual conservative evolution of certain section of the [[:es:Moderantismo|Moderados]]. One author notes that Janer himself sort of neared Traditionalist outlook during his academic years,<ref>''La Defensa'' 19.03.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1095519&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> yet his first public engagements did not demonstrate such a penchant. In the late 1850s and early 1860s he was noted for engagement in various institutions related to local business, recorded as member of [[:es:Instituto Agrícola Catalán de San Isidro|Instituto Agrícola Catalan]]<ref>''Revista de agricultura práctica, economía rural, horticultura y jardineria'', Barcelona 1855, available [http://www.bibgirona.cat/pandora/viewer.vm?id=0000634214&page=179&search= here]; during the lifetime of his father and for some time afterwards in the press Janer Gironella was referred to as "José de Janer", probably to avoid confusion with his father, usually noted as "Erasmo de Janer"; it was only later that he started to feature as "José Erasmo de Janer" and eventually as "Erasmo de Janer"</ref> and an insurance company ''La Providencia''<ref>''El Lloyd Español'' 12.08.62, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004064538&page=4 here]</ref> or sitting in the board of Asociación de Socorros y Protección a la Clase Obrera y Jornalera<ref>''La Corona'' 25.02.63, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026768560&page=7 here]</ref> and in Junta de Patronato of his Barcelona borough.<ref>''La Corona'' 19.06.63, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026770652&page=2 here]</ref> One source claims he initially practiced as a lawyer.<ref>B. de Artagan [Reynaldo Brea], ''Políticos del carlismo'', Barcelona 1912, p. 272</ref>
In the mid-1860s Janer was first noted running for public office, as propietario and haciendario competing for the concejal post in the Barcelona [[ayuntamiento]];<ref>''La Corona'' 01.11.64, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026779807&page=3 here]</ref> there is no confirmation of his success. It seems that during final years of the [[Isabella II of Spain|Isabelline monarchy]] he neared the entourage of the then capitán general of Catalonia and the [[Moderate Party (Spain)|Conservative]] politician, [[:es:Juan de la Pezuela|Juan de la Pezuela]]; Janer used to address him in public homage letters<ref>''Diario de Córdoba'' 18.08.68, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=4050048&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and was nominated by Pezuela to the last Isabelline city council, where he was sitting as the youngest [[Councillor|concejal]] until the body was dissolved during the [[Glorious Revolution (Spain)|1868 revolution]].<ref>''La Defensa'' 19.03.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1095519&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal en 1888.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal|Tirso Olazábal]]]] One author claims that Janer passed from Conservative to Carlist position when faced with the revolutionary developments of the late 1860s.<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo español'', vol. 28, Sevilla 1959, p. 293</ref> Some sources maintain he fielded his candidature in elections to the [[Spanish general election, 1869|Constituent Assembly of 1869]] and indeed in 1871 he was already reported as nominated by the regional Carlist junta as their representative in the [[Spanish general election, 1871|Cortes elections]] from [[Sant Feliu de Llobregat]],<ref>''La Independencia'' 20.02.71, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0027323561&page=17 here]</ref> the bid which proved unsuccessful. In 1872 Janer became president of Círculo Católico-Monárquico in Barcelona<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 272</ref> and entered the provincial party executive, noted as member of the Barcelona Junta Provincial Católico-Monárquica. In the council he was sitting with his father-in-law, Manuel Milá de la Roca,<ref>''La Regeneración'' 02.03.72, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026701939&page=1 here]</ref> and forged the lifelong friendship with the junta leader and later Catalan Carlist leader, [[Luis de Llauder y Dalmases]]. Following outbreak of the [[Third Carlist War]] Janer found himself the target of [[First Spanish Republic|Republican]] persecutions and had to flee the city a number of times.<ref>''Erasme de Janer i de Gónima'' entry, [in:] ''Gran Enciclopédia Catalana'' online, available [https://www.enciclopedia.cat/EC-GEC-0034318.xm here] l</ref> Eventually with his family<ref>when in France during the Third Carlist War Janer was accompanied at least by 2 children, Edina Polácska, ''Karlista emigráció Franciaországban (1872–1876)'' [PhD dissertation University of Szeged], Szeged 2008, p. 40</ref> he sought exile in France and settled in [[Saint Jean de Luz]].<ref>''La Defensa'' 19.03.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=1095519&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> According to one source he joined a small team, led by [[Tirso de Olazábal y Lardizábal|Tírso de Olazábal]] and busy procuring arms for the Carlist troops;<ref>''La Defensa'' 19.03.11</ref> it is likely that taking advantage of his wealth, Janer contributed financially.<ref>a number of sources claim vaguely that Janer dedicated his fortune to the Carlist cause, yet none of them provides any details, compare ''Erasme de Janer i de Gónima'' entry, [in:] ''Gran Enciclopédia Catalana'' online, available [https://www.enciclopedia.cat/EC-GEC-0034318.xml here], Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 159, Gemma Tribó Travería, ''El naixament de la fira i els grans propietaris'', [in:] ''L'Espai'' 2 (1999), p. 72, Creixell, Sala 2005, p. 181</ref>
==In the second row (1877-1888)== [[File:El Correo Catalan.png|thumb|left|''El Correo Catalan'' logotypes]] It is not clear whether Janer's massive property was embargoed during the war, whether he suffered any other persecutions and when he returned to Barcelona after the Carlist military defeat. A number of sources point vaguely to the late 1870s when claiming that together with Milá de la Roca and Llauder Janer was among co-founders of a new Carlist daily which would remain in print for the following 60 years, ''[[:es:El Correo Catalan|El Correo Catalan]]''.<ref>''El Norte'' 30.07.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3069163&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here], Artagan 1912, p. 272</ref> In 1879 he entered the Barcelona ayuntamiento<ref>''Diari Catalá'' 30.05.79, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3032856&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here], see also Cèlia Cañelles Julià, Rosa Toran, ''Els governs de la ciutat de Barcelona (1875-1930): Eleccions, partits i regidors. Diccionari biografic'', Barcelona 2014, available online [https://books.google.es/books?id=DRzHAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT184&dq=erasme+janer+gironella&hl=pl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjl1fSh4ubZAhWjyKYKHZogALwQ6AEINjAC#v=onepage&q=erasme%20janer%20gironella&f=false here]</ref> yet duration of his term is not known; except a 1888 spell in Junta Municipal<ref>''La Dinastía'' 17.08.88, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001504024&page=2 here]</ref> it proved to be a unique Janer's episode in official administration. In the 1880s he was noted rather for looking after his family enterprises, especially in Caja de Ahorros.<ref>''La Dinastía'' 08.03.84, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001332479&page=2 here]</ref> However, some scholars claim that he demonstrated neither interest nor skills in commercial activities and that during his tenure the family business went into decline;<ref>Ceixell, Sala 2005, p. 181; the authors claim that Janer Gironella did not demonstrate much interest in family business. His stand gave rise to "three generations theory", namely that a family business can be sustained and developed during 3 generations only</ref> some go as far as to claim that to sustain the Carlist cause he kept selling off his private property<ref>in the early 20th century Janer Gironella sold his rural property in Sant Feliu de Llobregat, Tribó Travería 1999, p. 72</ref> or even that he ruined his fortune with the legitimist zeal.<ref>Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 159</ref> Janer was also known for engagement in numerous public initiatives, often flavored with charity: he held executive or presidential positions in Junta de Obra, Junta de la Beneficiencia in his Nuestra Señora del Carmen parish, Real Archicofradía de la Virgén de los Dolores,<ref>Artagan 1912, p. 272</ref> Junta Local de Salvament de Náufrags<ref>Cañelles Julià, Toran 2014</ref> and various makeshift committees, e.g. the body assisting victims of the 1885 [[earthquake]] in [[Andalusia]].<ref>''La Ilustración'' 11.01.85, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001419348&page=15 here]</ref> [[File:Lluís Maria de Llauder i de Dalmases.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Luis de Llauder y Dalmases|Lluís Llauder Dalmases]]]] In the 1880s Carlism did not exist as organized structures present in the Spanish public life; the movement languished as a set of loose quasi-political initiatives flavored with Traditionalist spirit and intransigent religiosity. Part of this strategy was mobilizing support by means of mass pilgrimages; Janer contributed as member of the Barcelona Junta Organizativa branch, which co-ordinated the 1882 [[romería]] to [[Rome]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.01.82, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000060006&page=2 here]</ref> Adhering to the same line he used to sign various public letters denouncing perceived injustice to the Catholics and secular course of the government, e.g. the entire Janer family subscribed to a 1883 document which protested curtailment of Catholic rights;<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 14.06.83, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000069956&page=1 here]</ref> in 1884 he emerged as leader of the Catalan branch of Asociación Católica.<ref>Cañelles Julià, Toran 2014</ref> Stress on religious features, focus on Traditionalist values and de-emphasizing of dynastical threads was very much the vision of the Carlist political leader [[:es:Candido Nocedal|Candido Nocedal]] and later his son [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón]]. Janer seemed on perfect terms with both<ref>compare his taking part in initiatives of Nocedal and Sarda y Salvany, ''El Ancora'' 17.01.82, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2225936&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> despite the fact that the Nocedalistas, known also as [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrists]], were increasingly on collision course with the claimant [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Don Carlos]]; as late as in 1886 Janer took part in a homage banquet honoring Ramón Nocedal.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 10.03.86, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000099159&page=2 here]</ref> However, when in 1888 the Integrists broke away from Carlism to form their own Traditionalist organization Janer decided to stay loyal to his king; in 1889 he was already lambasted by the Integrists as the sidekick of Llauder.<ref>''La Fidelidad Castellana'' 20.05.89, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1068123&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=3 here]</ref>
==Deputy leader (1889-1901)== [[File:De Cerralbo.JPG|thumb|160px|left|[[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|Marques de Cerralbo]]]] Following the Integrist secession Carlism abandoned its quasi-political format of the 1880s and assumed a decisively more active political stance; the nationwide structures started to emerge, initially styled as committees celebrating 1,400 years since the [[:es:Conversión de Recaredo|Conversion of Recaredo]]. In Catalonia the organization was headed by Llauder, yet Janer – together with Manuel de Torrents – was nominated its vice-president, effectively the second-in-command in the regional party infrastructure.<ref>Jordi Canal, ''El carlisme catala dins l'Espanya de la restauracio: un assaig de modernització politica (1888-1900)'', Barcelona 1998, {{ISBN|9788476022436}}, p. 79</ref> However, his contribution to Carlist buildup seems meager. Though Carlist candidates started to take part in electoral campaigns and under the new nationwide leadership of [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|Marqués de Cerralbo]] the movement took shape of an organized modern political party, there is little information on Janer's public activity in the early 1890s. Despite consolidation and growth of Catalan Carlism under the regional leadership of Llauder, Janer neither stood as candidate in elections nor was recorded as active in supporting electoral campaigns. While de Cerralbo was striving to implement a new formula of mass mobilization<ref>on the new format of Carlism as build by de Cerralbo see Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012</ref> Janer seemed attached rather to old-style patterns and at best took part in closed-door party feasts, like the one in 1893.<ref>''El Correo Español'' 14.02.93, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029793065&page=2 here]</ref> His popular initiatives stuck to the pilgrimage format, e.g. when organizing workers' romería to Rome in 1894<ref>''El Correo Español'' 22.02.94, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029793843&page=2 here]</ref> or signing homage letter to the [[papal nuncio]]; the document protested the governmental secularization policy.<ref>''La Dinastía'' 28.10.94, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001611057&page=2 here]</ref> [[File:Carlos Duke of Madrid.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Don Carlos]]]] In 1895 Janer was officially confirmed by de Cerralbo as vice-president of the Catalan Carlist organization,<ref>''El Baluarte'' 10.10.95, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1001468&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=3 here]</ref> yet he still remained in the shadow of Llauder. He was barely mentioned when new party círculos in the region were being opened, typically noted when presiding over official banquets<ref>Canal 1998, p. 177</ref> or entertaining royal Carlist figures, e.g. the second wife of the claimant Berthe do Rohan, who visited Barcelona in 1896.<ref>''El Correo Español'' 16.12.96, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029797312&page=1 here]</ref> Though historiographic studies either on Catalan<ref>a monograph on Catal Carlism during the late 19th century mentions Janer only 2 times in rather episodical roles, see Canal 1998</ref> or nationwide Carlism<ref>the work nearest to the overall history of late 19th century Carlism does not mention Janer at all, compare Fernández Escudero 2012</ref> of the 1890s barely mention his name, de Cerralbo was apparently satisfied with Janer's contribution to the cause; Jefe Delegado addressed him with effusive letters of gratitude and thanked him for electoral efforts;<ref>''Correo de Tortosa'' 28.9.96</ref> press of the era provides little evidence of such support.<ref>''El Correo Español'' 18.09.96</ref> Actually, it seems that in the late 1890s the Catalan Carlism was vibrant yet increasingly leaderless and disorganized. Since 1898 due to his poor health Llauder's leadership became largely theoretical, while the movement was plagued by personal squabbles, emerging social radicalism, urban [[pistolerismo]], [[Catalanism|Catalanist]] sympathies and insurrectional currents. None of the sources consulted mentions Janer when discussing the local [[:es:Sublevación carlista de octubre de 1900|1899-1900 Carlist revolts in Catalonia]].<ref>Janer is not a single time mentioned in works dealing in detail with the Carlist conspiracy and revolts of 1899-1900, see Joan Villarroya i Font, ''1900. Els carlins a l'assalt de Badalona'', [in:] ''Carrer dels Abres'' 1 (1990), pp. 69-76, Eduardo González Calleja, Jordi Canal, ''No era la ocasión propicia..... La conspiración carlista de fin de siglo en un memorial a don Carlos'', [in:] ''Hispania'' 181 (1992), pp. 705-742, Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Las derechas españólas ante la crisis del 98'', [in:] ''Studia Historica'' 15 (1997), pp. 193-219</ref> The press noted that in the very first years of the 20th century the Catalan Carlism was led by 3 competitive juntas: 1) the old one headed by Llauder, 2) the new one appointed by recently nominated Jefe Delegado [[Matías Barrio y Mier|Matiás Barrio]] and headed by [[Manuel de Llanza y Pignatelli|Duque de Solferino]], and 3) the one associated with [[:es:José B. Moore|general Moore]], headed by Janer;<ref>''Luz Católica'' 10.04.02, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005385461&page=14 here]</ref> this claim is not confirmed by other sources. Following the death of Llauder and despite rumors pointing to Solferino, following Janer's visit to Don Carlos' residence in [[Venice]]<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 09.06.03, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7114107&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in 1902 the claimant nominated him the new Catalan leader.<ref>''La Epoca'' 02.07.02, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000681305&page=3 here]</ref>
==''Jefe'' (1902-1910)== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] Janer's tenure fell on a period when Catalan Carlism was challenged by massive social and political change, the decade which shifted the region's centre of gravity from rural traditional hinterland to the coastal strip, dominated by new urban classes. The rising Catalanist and anti-establishment tide gave rise to [[Catalan Solidarity (1906)|Solidaridad Catalana]]; on the one hand the Carlists were attracted by its opposition to the [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]] regime, on the other they were estranged by [[Republicanism in Spain|Republican]], [[Catalan nationalism|nationalist]] and secularist features of the alliance. Janer, who in 1903-1905 limited himself to making appointments<ref>''La Lucha'' 13.07.05, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1077455&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and presiding over party feasts,<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 18.05.93, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000507516&page=1 here]</ref> in 1906 gave in to the pressure of pro-Solidaridad Carlists like Solferino and [[:es:miguel junyent|Junyent]] and permitted access to the pact. His key concern was that only authorized individuals were allowed to stand on joint electoral lists<ref>''El Correo Español'' 09.05.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029806932&page=2 here]</ref> and that the move did not go beyond a temporary tactical cooperation.<ref>''La Tarde'' 02.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1104760&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Faced with anti-Solidaridad opposition in the party ranks<ref>e.g. the Catalan branch of Juventud Carlista protested to Janer over taking part in alliance with overtly pro-republican and secular zealots, ''La Cruz'' 17.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3046469&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he enforced discipline<ref>Albert Balcells, Joan B. Culla, Conxita Mir, ''Les eleccions generals a Catalunya de 1901 a 1923'', Barcelona 1982, pp. 122-123; in 1908 Janer dissolved a local branch for opposition to official policy, ''La Correspondencia de España'' 12.09.98, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000587982&page=2 here]</ref> yet it seems he kept vacillating himself.<ref>the press provides conflicting evidence of Janer's stand towards Solidaridad, compare ''El Intransigente'' 09.04.07, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029755530&page=2 here], ''La Tarde'' 02.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1104760&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here], ''La Reconquista'' 06.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1015247&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here], ''La Lucha'' 07.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1079420&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Carlist access was rewarded with [[Electoral Carlism (Restoration)|great success in the 1907 elections]]<ref>the claimant congratulated Janer on excellent electoral results, ''La Lucha'' 11.05.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1079447&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> but it seems that Janer had few regrets when the alliance fell apart in 1908, even though debates persisted until 1909.<ref>in 1909 Solferino resigned from provincial Barcelona jefatura due to differences with Janer over strategy for forthcoming elections, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 01.12.09, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000286038&page=3 here], ''El Restaurador'' 01.12.09, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1014600&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Another problem Janer had to face as a regional leader was the insurrectional tide, rising among the Catalan Carlists. Though the 1900 preparations boiled down to few isolated attempts some sections of the party kept gearing up for a violent overthrow of the regime. Janer called for discipline and tried to marginalize the radicals;<ref>''La Rioja'' 06.02.06, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3081688&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagin here] a</ref> when in 1906 they staged a [[:es:Guillermo Moore|local revolt in Martorell]], easily crushed by the government forces, Janer first disauthorised the action<ref>''El Correo Español'' 19.09.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029807472&page=1 here]</ref> and then expulsed the insurrectionists from the party,<ref>''El Correo Español'' 20.10.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029807602&page=2 here]</ref> again in full agreement with the claimant.<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 28.09.06, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000533648&page=1 here]</ref> However, the dissent was mounting, fuelled also by personal squabbles and issues related to tactical alliances with the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsists]]; to enforce discipline at times Janer opted for dissolution of municipal<ref>see e.g. the 1906 Valls affair, related Joaquín Avella and his Alfonsist leaning, ''El Porvenir'' 1.12.06; other titles claimed the problem was rather about Solidaridad, see ''La Cronica de Valls'' 10.8.07</ref> or even provincial party jefaturas.<ref>in May 1907 Janer dissolved Junta Provincial of Tarragona in relation to its stand on elections to the Senate, ''La Cruz'' 25.05.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3046501&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> A few local party heavyweights like [[Josep de Suelves i de Montagut|Tamarít]] grumbled against Janer and some, like Solferino, resigned in protest.<ref>''Las Provincias'' 07.04.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000312848&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Vich 1906.jpg|thumb|160px|Janer at a Carlist feast in [[Vic]]h, 1908]] Janer seemed overwhelmed by problems and apparent decomposition of the party in Catalonia; he first tried to step down in 1906, but his resignation was not accepted by the claimant;<ref>''La Tarde'' 10.07.06, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1103443&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in 1908 he again handed over his resignation, also to no avail.<ref>''El Día'' 15.03.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002528282&page=3 here]</ref> Contemporary press noted that Janer was a great Christian, grand citizen and by all means an extraordinary person, but neither a good leader nor an impressive politician, tending to inactivity and with scarce faith in the cause.<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 15.09.04, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000503807&page=4 here]</ref> He is not recorded as engaged in heated debates shaping the nationwide Carlist politics.<ref>in 1909-1912 Carlism was increasingly paralysed by the conflict between the key party theorist [[Juan Vázquez de Mella|Vázquez de Mella]] and the official party leader Bartolomé Feliú; Janer has not been mentioned by any study related, see Fernández Escudero 2012, Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, ISBN 97884878638202, and Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El caso Feliú y el dominio de Mella en el partido carlista en el período 1909-1912'', [in:] ''Espacio, tiempo y forma'' 10 (1997), pp. 99–116</ref> In 1910 Janer eventually got his resignation accepted by the new Carlist king [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], who appointed Solferino his successor.<ref>''La Hórmiga de Oro'' 19.02.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0012093769&page=13 here]</ref> The reason quoted was Janer's poor health<ref>''El Bien Público'' 20.01.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000139152&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and indeed it seems that his life force deteriorated, especially after the 1910 death of his wife. Following resignation he mostly withdrew into privacy and in public remained engaged only in family business, until death performing managerial duties in Caja de Ahorros.<ref>Wray McDonogh 2014, p. 159</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Eugene Chen | image = Chen_Youren.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | native_name = {{zh|t=陳友仁|s=陈友仁|p=Chén Yǒurén}} | native_name_lang = zh | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1878|7|2}} | birth_place = [[San Fernando, Trinidad and Tobago|San Fernando, Trinidad]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1944|5|20|1878|7|2|df=y}} | death_place = [[Shanghai]], [[Reorganized National Government of the Republic of China|China]] | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery]], [[Beijing]], [[China]] | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | nationality = | other_names = Eugene Bernard Achan
Chen Youren | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | known_for = | spouse = {{marriage|Agatha Alphosin Ganteaume|1899|1926|end=died}}
{{marriage|[[Georgette Chen]]|1930|May 20, 1944}} | children = {{unbulleted list|[[Percy Chen]]|Sylvia Chen (daughter)|Yolanda Chen (daughter)|[[Jack Chen]] (son)}} | mother = Mary Longchallon | father = Chen Guangquan | relatives = | family = | module = {{Chinese |child=yes |t=陳友仁|s=陈友仁|p=Chén Yǒurén|w=Ch'en Yu-jen}} }} '''Eugene Chen''' or '''Chen Youren''' ({{zh|t=陳友仁|w='''Ch'en Yu-jen'''}}; July 2, 1878, [[San Fernando, Trinidad and Tobago|San Fernando, Trinidad]]{{cite web|url=http://yuantsungchen.com/images/Birth%20Certificate%20-%20Jack.jpg |accessdate=October 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418205323/http://www.yuantsungchen.com/images/Birth%20Certificate%20-%20Jack.jpg |archivedate=April 18, 2012 }} – 20 May 1944, [[Shanghai]]), known in his youth as '''Eugene Bernard Achan''', was an [[overseas Chinese]] lawyer who in the 1920s became [[Sun Yat-sen]]'s foreign minister. He was known for his success in promoting Sun's anti-imperialist foreign policies.{{cite journal|title=Eugene Chen|author1=Howard L. Boorman|author2=Richard C. Howard|journal=Biographical Dictionary of Republican China|location=New York|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|date=1967|volume=I|pages=180–183}} ==Early years== Chen's father, Chen Guangquan, was known as Joseph Chen or Achan. He was of [[Hakka]] ancestry from [[Meixian District|Meixian]]. After taking part in the [[Taiping Rebellion]] against the [[Manchu dynasty]], he fled to the [[French West Indies]] where he met his wife, Mary Longchallon (Marie Leong), also a Chinese immigrant. Chen, as well as the Longchallon family, had been required by the French authorities to accept the Catholic faith as a condition of immigration. Eugene was the oldest of Chen Guangquan and Mary Longchallon's three sons. Both parents of Eugene Chen were Chinese immigrants to Trinidad. His wife Aisy was of African and French blood. ===Education=== After attending a Catholic school, St Mary's College, Trinidad, Chen qualified as a barrister and became known as one of the most highly skilled solicitors in the islands.Boorman, p. 180. The family did not speak Chinese at home; and, since there were no Chinese schools, he also did not learn to read [[Chinese script|Chinese]]. It was later said of him that his library was filled with Dickens, Shakespeare, Scott, and legal books, that he "spoke English as a scholar"; "except for his color, neither his living nor his habits were Chinese".{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fMrit6tcO_AC&pg=PA239&lpg=PA239&dq=Eugene+Chen+-Eoyang&source=bl&ots=bTDF2uE1iS&sig=fNhYCDltyl3G43xTJTaery9h3D4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=42J2UKHEIKSryQGZn4DIDw&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Eugene%20Chen%20-Eoyang&f=false | title=Eugene Chen | accessdate=October 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101061322/https://books.google.com/books?id=fMrit6tcO_AC&pg=PA239&lpg=PA239&dq=Eugene+Chen+-Eoyang&source=bl&ots=bTDF2uE1iS&sig=fNhYCDltyl3G43xTJTaery9h3D4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=42J2UKHEIKSryQGZn4DIDw&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCQ |archivedate=January 1, 2014 }} ==Professional life== Chen eventually left the island to live in London, where he heard [[Sun Yat-sen]] speak at a rally against the Manchu government in China. Sun persuaded him to come to China and contribute his legal knowledge to the new Republic in 1912. Chen took the [[Trans-Siberian Railroad]], and shared the journey with [[Wu Liande|Wu Lien-te]], a physician born in Malaysia. Learning that Chen had no Chinese name, Wu suggested "Youren" as the equivalent of "Eugene". After Sun was forced to flee to Japan in 1913, Chen remained in Peking, where he began a second career in journalism. Chen edited the bilingual ''Peking Gazette'' 1913-1917, then founded the ''Shanghai Gazette'', the first of what Sun envisioned as a network of newspapers across China.{{cite web|url=http://chinaheritagenewsletter.anu.edu.au/features.php?searchterm=030_wagner.inc&issue=030 |accessdate=October 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes|title=China Heritage Newsletter |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029214201/http://chinaheritagenewsletter.anu.edu.au/features.php?searchterm=030_wagner.inc&issue=030 |archivedate=October 29, 2013 }} Chen had given up his initial support for [[Yuan Shikai]] and became a strong critic of the government, accusing it of "selling China", for which offence he was imprisoned.{{cite web|url=http://yuantsungchen.com/images/Archive/Peking%20Gazette%201917%2005%2018.pdf |accessdate=October 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes|title=Peking Gazette |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216231823/http://yuantsungchen.com/images/Archive/Peking%20Gazette%201917%2005%2018.pdf |archivedate=February 16, 2012 }} In 1918, Chen joined Sun in Canton to support the southern government, which he helped to represent at the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]], where he resisted Japanese and British plans for China. In 1922, Chen became Sun's closest adviser on foreign affairs, and developed a leftist stance of [[Anti-imperialism|anti-imperialist]] nationalism and support of Sun's alliance with the [[Soviet Union]].Boorman,p. 181. ===Chen's revolutionary diplomacy=== Chen's diplomacy led one historian to call him "arguably China's most important diplomat of the 1920s and instrumental in the rights recovery movement."Philip C.C. Huang, "Biculturality in Modern China and in Chinese Studies," ''Modern China'' 26.1 (2000), p. 13. Chen welcomed Sun's alliance with the Soviet Union, and worked harmoniously with [[Michael Borodin]], the chief Soviet and foreign policy adviser to Sun Yat-Sen on the reorganization of the [[Guomindang|Nationalist Party]] at Canton in 1923. After Sun's death, Chen was elected to the Central Executive Committee of Kuomintang, Nationalist Minister for Foreign affairs at Canton, and Ruler of Hankow, all being achieved in 1926 he was forced to resign in April 1927. Over the next two years, Chen lodged vigorous and articulate protests over continued imperialist policies with the American and British governments, as well as negotiating with the British authorities over the massive labor strikes in Hong Kong. When Chiang Kai-shek's [[Northern Expedition]] appeared on the verge of unifying the country, Chen joined the [[Government of the Republic of China in Wuhan|rival Nationalist government]] at [[Wuhan#National government moved its capital to Wuhan|Wuhan]]. In January 1927, the Nationalists at Wuhan forcibly took control over the foreign concession there, and when violent crowds also took the foreign concession at [[Kiukiang]], foreign warships gathered at Shanghai. Chen's negotiations with the British led to confirmation of Chinese control of the two concessions and this success was hailed as the start of a new revolutionary foreign policy. The situation soon reversed. The foreign powers retaliated for the deadly xenophobic attacks on foreigners by elements of the [[National Revolutionary Army]] in Nanking, and Chiang Kai-shek launched [[Shanghai massacre of 1927|White Terror attacks]] on leftists in Shanghai.Boorman, p.182-183 Chen sent Borodin, his sons [[Percy Chen]] and [[Jack Chen]], and the American leftist journalist [[Anna Louise Strong]] in an automotive convoy across Central Asia to Moscow. He, his daughters Si-lan and Yolanda,Mme. Sun Yat-sen, and the American journalist [[Rayna Prohme]] traveled from Shanghai to Vladivostok, and once again by Trans-Siberian Railway to Moscow.Percy Chen, ''China Called Me: My Life Inside the Chinese Revolution'' (Boston: Little Brown, 1979) [[File:1927年宋庆龄陈友仁在莫斯科.jpg|thumb|300px|1927 Chen and Soong Qingling in Moscow]] Life in Moscow from 1928 was far from easy. After an initial warm public reception, Stalin showed little tolerance for living symbols of the Soviet failure in China. Chen and Mme. Sun were frustrated in their attempts to establish a leftist Chinese front, and soon left Moscow. After a period of exile he went to Hong Kong before being appointed Foreign Minister by General [[Chiang Kai-Shek]] in 1931. After brief service with governments in China which challenged the Nanking government, Chen was finally expelled from the Kuomintang for serving as Foreign Minister in the [[Fukien Rebellion]] of 1934. He again took refuge in Paris, but returned to Hong Kong after the outbreak of the [[Second Sino-Japanese War|war with Japan]]. He was taken to Shanghai in the spring of 1942 in hopes of persuading him to support the [[Reorganized National Government of China|Japanese puppet government]], but he remained loudly critical of that "pack of liars" until his death in May, 1944, at the age of 66.Boorman, p. 180-181. ==Personal life== In 1899, Chen married Agatha Alphosin Ganteaume (1878–1926), known as Aisy, a French Creole whose father owned one of the largest estates in Trinidad. They had eight children, four of whom survived childhood: [[Percy Chen]] (1901-1986), a lawyer, worked with his father for many years; Sylvia (Silan) Chen (1905-1996), an internationally known dancer, married the American film historian [[Jay Leyda]]; Yolanda (Yulen) Chen (1913-2006), who stayed in the USSR for the rest of her life and came to the prominence as a camerawoman; and [[Jack Chen]] (1908-1995), who made an international reputation as a journalistic cartoonist during the Sino-Japanese War, and who wrote [[A Year In Upper Felicity]], an account of his experience in the countryside during the [[Cultural Revolution]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?lr=&id=t8wdOqCde-YC&q=Alphonsine#v=snippet&q=Alphonsine&f=false |title=Return to the Middle Kingdom: One Family, Three Revolutionaries, and the ... - Yuan-tsung Chen - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-01}} In 1958 Jack married [[Chen Yuan-tsung]]. Aisy died of breast cancer in May 1926. Chen and [[Georgette Chen]] were married in 1930 and remained together until his death in 1944. ==Sources== * Percy Chen, ''China called Me: My Life Inside the Chinese Revolution''. Boston: Little Brown, 1979. 423p. {{ISBN|0316138495}}. Sheldon Ridge; “Life Story of Eugene Chen” (furnished by American Legation, July 1927).{{cite web |title=Colonial Office Report: Eugene Ch'en |date=15 February 1927 |url=http://yuantsungchen.com/images/Colonial%20Office%20Report.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029192825/http://yuantsungchen.com/images/Colonial%20Office%20Report.pdf |archive-date=29 October 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{PM20|FID=pe/003195}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chen, Eugene}} [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Chinese Roman Catholics]] [[Category:People from Meixian District]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Foreign Ministers of the Republic of China]] [[Category:Hakka people]] [[Category:Chinese Christians]] [[Category:People of the Chinese Civil War]] [[Category:1872 births]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago people of Hakka descent]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:Trinidad and Tobago lawyers]]

[[Image:Boldini - Florence, Lady Phillips.jpg|thumb|right|Florence, Lady Phillips by 1903 Oil on canvas 193 x 155 cm by [[Giovanni Boldini]] (1842 – 1931) Dublin City Gallery, The Hugh Lane]] '''Dorothea Sarah Florence Alexandra, Lady Phillips''' (née Ortlepp; 14 June 1863 – 23 August 1940) was a [[South Africa]]n art patroness and promoter of indigenous culture. She was married to [[Lionel Phillips|Sir Lionel Phillips, 1st Baronet]], a mining magnate and politician and was known by one of her middle names, Florence.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.artefacts.co.za/main/Buildings/archframes.php?archid=5973|title=PHILLIPS, Lady Florence|website=www.artefacts.co.za|access-date=2017-10-10}}</ref>
==Early life== Florence Ortlepp was born in [[Cape Town]] in 1863, the only daughter of Albert Frederick Ortlepp, a Colesberg land surveyor and naturalist, and Sarah Walker. She received her education at [[Rondebosch]] and later in [[Bloemfontein]]. Lionel Phillips met her on the diamond-diggings and married her in 1885. They moved to Johannesburg in 1889. She travelled extensively from 1887, but returned hurriedly to be with her husband during his trial following the [[Jameson Raid]]. After his sentence, reprieve and exile, they left for London and established a home in [[Grosvenor Square]] while maintaining a country house at Tylney Hall in Hampshire. While the couple lived in London, Florence acquired a keen interest in art and bought numerous works by artists of the time, including [[William Orpen]], [[William Rothenstein]], [[Walter Sickert]], [[Philip Wilson Steer]], [[Camille Pissarro]], [[Claude Monet]] and [[Alfred Sisley]]. She presented many of these works to the Johannesburg Art Gallery, which she actively helped to establish.
On a visit to South Africa in 1905, she commissioned [[Rudolf Marloth]] to undertake his Flora of South Africa, a mammoth work published in 6 volumes between 1913 and 1932. [[Image:Florence Phillips.jpg|thumb|Lady Phillips 1909 Oil on canvas 89 x 75 cm by [[Antonio Mancini]] (1852 - 1930) Courtesy Johannesburg Art Gallery]]
==Art collection== After resettling in Johannesburg, she started acquiring paintings with a view to eventually founding an art gallery, which after many difficulties took shape as the [[Johannesburg Art Gallery]]. She played a leading role in projects aimed at cultivating and preserving the local artistic heritage. She persuaded Sir [[Max Michaelis]] to donate his considerable collection of 17th century Dutch and Flemish paintings to the city of [[Cape Town]]. She headed a movement to preserve and restore the [[Koopmans-de Wet House|Koopmans-De Wet House]] in Cape Town and was an enthusiastic collector of Africana furniture, both for her own home and public institutions. She was instrumental, with Prof. G.E. Pearse, in establishing a Faculty of Architecture at the [[University of the Witwatersrand]].
== Literary output == [[Image:Florence Phillips01.jpg|thumb|Florence, Lady Phillips c1910 by [[Sir William Nicholson]] (1872-1949) Oil on canvas 112 x 92 cm. Johannesburg Art Gallery]] In 1913 her book "A Friendly Germany: Why Not?" was published pleading for friendly relations between England and Germany. She was of the opinion that Britain and Germany should unite against the self-determination movement amongst the Asians and Africans, which she referred to as "The Black and the Yellow Perils".
==Later life== Florence and Lionel Phillips eventually settled at the farm [[Vergelegen]] near Somerset West in 1924. Here they devoted their spare time to encouraging the preservation of national heritage culture and artefacts. They also sponsored immigrants through the 1820 Settlers Memorial Association and a number of other public causes. Many of the [[Randlords]] and their wives commissioned portraits of themselves from leading European society portraitists of the time. The living room of the Vergelegen Manor House is adorned by a youthful and opulent portrayal of Florence by the Italian artist [[Giovanni Boldini]], while a more mature and sombre rendering by the British portraitist [[Sir William Nicholson]] is to be seen in the Music Room. The Boldini portrait was presented by Lady Phillips to the SA National Gallery in the 1930s.
She died in 1940<ref name=":0" /> at [[Vergelegen]], [[Somerset West]]. She and her husband are buried in the Brixton Cemetery in Johannesburg. They had two sons and a daughter.

{{italic title}} [[File:Foxygrandpa1904.jpg|right|240px|thumb|[[Carl E. Schultze]]'s ''Foxy Grandpa'' (1904)]] '''''Foxy Grandpa''''' was an American [[gag-a-day]] newspaper [[comic strip]] featuring an eponymous character, created by [[cartoonist]] [[Carl E. Schultze]] drawing under the name of “Bunny.”
''Foxy Grandpa'' made its first appearance on January 7, 1900.<ref name=lambiek-schultze>{{Cite web|last=[[Lambiek]] Comiclopedia|title= Carl Edward Schultze|url=http://lambiek.net/artists/s/schultze_carl.htm}}</ref> The strip initially ran in the ''[[New York Herald]]'', but it moved to the ''[[New York American]]'' on February 16, 1902.<ref name=toonopedia-foxy>{{cite web |last= Don Markstein's [[Toonopedia]] |title= Foxy Grandpa|url=http://www.toonopedia.com/foxygran.htm }}</ref>
[[Selchow and Righter]] licensed ''Foxy Grandpa'' for the Foxy Grandpa Hat Party Game (similar to [[Pin the Tail on the Donkey]]) after 1900. Between 1901 and 1917, ''Foxy Grandpa'' was published in books, more than 30 volumes from four different publishers. The strip was also adapted to Broadway shows and early silent films (with Foxy Grandpa played by stage performer [[Joseph Hart (entertainer)|Joseph Hart]]). In 1912, the strip was briefly distributed by the [[C. J. Mar Syndicate]], but it was dropped in 1918.
In the typeset ''Foxy Grandpa's Stories'', distributed by [[Newspaper Feature Syndicate]], Foxy Grandpa was the narrator, appearing in a one-panel cartoon at the top of each column. This feature lasted through the 1920s and well into the 1930s. In 1929, the strip appeared in America's first comics periodical, ''[[The Funnies]]''.<ref name=toonopedia-foxy/>
==Characters and story== The strip revolved around Foxy Grandpa, an elderly gentleman, with two mischievous grandsons (Chub and Bunt) who constantly try to trick him. Foxy Grandpa, however, always managed to get the better of the two boys, combining brains with a perverse sense of humor, while demonstrating skills at acrobatics, illustration and construction of various small devices.<ref name=toonopedia-foxy/>
The comic was drawn in [[text comics|text comic]] style, with the text and dialogue written underneath the images.
==Cultural legacy== *In the 1938 film [[Crashing Hollywood (1938 film)|''Crashing Hollywood'']] the squirrelly Movie mogul Hugo Wells is called "Foxy Grandpa". *In the 1944 film ''[[Murder My Sweet]]'' detective [[Phillip Marlowe]] refers to the villainous Jules Amthor as "Foxy Grandpa". *In the ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' episode "One Krab's Trash," "Foxy Grandpa" is written on a trucker hat offered to [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|SpongeBob SquarePants]] by his boss, Mr. Krabs. *In the [[Pogo (comic strip)|Pogo]] strip for Sunday, April 8, 1951, Rackety Coon Chile and Alabaster Allligator are less than thrilled with a story being told to them by Albert and wonder if they might be able to move to another strip. Alabaster suggests "Foxey [sic] Grandpa".
==References== {{reflist}}

'''George Rae''' (1817-1902) was a British banker and stockbroker based in [[Birkenhead]]. He is most notable for his patronage of the [[Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]] and his commissioning and acquisition of works by [[Ford Madox Brown]], [[Arthur Hughes (artist)|Arthur Hughes]] and [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/about/collections/featured-artists/Dante-Gabriel-Rossetti.aspx |title= Collections and research - Featured artists - Dante Gabriel Rossetti |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=National Museums Liverpool |publisher= |access-date=2017-09-27}}</ref> His commissions included Rossetti's ''[[The Beloved (Rossetti painting)|The Beloved]]'', commissioned in 1863 for £300 but only completed two years later. <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/rossetti-the-beloved-the-bride-n03053 |title=Dante Gabriel Rossetti, The Beloved (‘The Bride’), 1865–6 |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Tate Britain |publisher= |access-date=2017-09-27}}</ref> He also acquired landscapes by local [[Liverpool]] artists like William J Bond and [[William Davis (artist)|William Davis]], hanging his collection in Redcourt, his house in the [[Wirral Peninsula|Wirral]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.artinliverpool.com/williamson-gallery-george-rae-of-birkenhead-and-his-pre-raphaelite-collection/ |title=Williamson Gallery: George Rae of Birkenhead and his Pre-Raphaelite collection |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=artinliverpool.com |publisher= |access-date= 2017-09-27}}</ref>
==References== <references/>

[[Harvard University]] (1941) | employer =[[Manhattan Project]]
[[General Electric Company]] | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse ={{marriage|Alma Rosenbaum |1951}} | partner = | children = | parents =Henry Hurwitz Sr. | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Henry Hurwitz Jr.''' (December 25, 1918 – April 14, 1992), was a physicist at [[General Electric Company]] who pioneered the theory and design of nuclear power plants and helped engineer the reactor for the [[USS Seawolf (SSN-575)|Seawolf]] nuclear submarine. ==Biography== He was born in Manhattan on December 25, 1918. He graduated from [[Cornell University]] in 1938, with an [[Master of Science|M.S.]] in physics. He then went to [[Harvard University]] in 1939 and received a [[Ph.D.]] in quantum mechanics in 1941. His first marriage ended in divorce. In 1943 he was recruited by [[Hans Bethe]] to help [[Edward Teller]]'s staff of researchers at the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] in New Mexico develop the thermonuclear reactions for the [[hydrogen bomb]]. In 1946, Hurwitz became one of the first scientists to work at GE's [[Knolls Atomic Power Laboratory]] in [[Schenectady, New York]]. In 1947 he transferred to the GE Research and Development Center to become manager of the Nucleonics and Radiation Branch. His team of scientists used advanced theta-pinch techniques to harness fusion reactions. In 1955, a year after [[Fortune Magazine]] named him as one of the top 10 scientists in U.S. industry, Hurwitz contributed to establishing the first atomic containment sphere for [[GE]]. The development advanced industry-wide safety protocols for enclosing nuclear reactors. His interest in electronic devices, computer applications, and chemical engineering prompted GE to recognize Hurwitz's accomplishments in 1975 by naming him a Coolidge Fellow, the GE R&D Center's highest honor. Hurwitz also is noted for his efforts to raise awareness about the dangers of [[Radon]], and later received the [[Glenn T. Seaborg Medal]] in 1989 from the [[American Nuclear Society]]. He died on April 14, 1992 in [[Schenectady, New York]] of [[cancer]], at age 73.{{Cite news | last = Lambert | first = Bruce | title = Henry Hurwitz, 73; Research Physicist Developed Reactors | publisher = [[New York Times]] | quote = Henry Hurwitz Jr., a research physicist who worked on plans for the hydrogen bomb and later helped develop nuclear power plants, died on Tuesday at his home in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 73 years old. He died of cancer, his family said. | date = April 16, 1992 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE4DA1738F935A25757C0A964958260}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite web | title = People Briefs: Henry Hurwitz Jr. | publisher = The Scientist | date = May 25, 1992 | url = http://www.the-scientist.com/article/display/11375/}} *{{Cite web | title = Henry Hurwitz | publisher = Access to Energy Newsletter | date = June 1, 1992 | url = http://www.accesstoenergy.com/view/atearchive/s76a5755.htm}} *{{Cite web |title=Henry Hurwitz Jr. |publisher=The Earnest Orlando Lawrence Award |year=1961 |url=http://www.science.doe.gov/lawrence/html/Laureates/1960s/henryh.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016043340/http://www.science.doe.gov/lawrence/html/Laureates/1960s/henryh.htm |archivedate=2007-10-16 |df= }} *{{Cite web | title = Henry Hurwitz Jr. | publisher = Seaborg Medal | year = 1961 | url = http://www.ans.org/honors/recipients/va-seaborg}} *{{cite news | title = Henry Hurwitz Jr. on Radon | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DEEDD1239F930A2575AC0A961948260&sec=&spon= | work=The New York Times | date=September 13, 1987 | accessdate=May 4, 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hurwitz, Henry Jr.}} [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:American nuclear physicists]] [[Category:Jewish American scientists]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:1992 deaths]] [[Category:Theoretical physicists]]

'''James Ross''' (9 May 1835 – 20 September 1871) was a Metis [[journalist]], [[lawyer]], and member of the [[provisional government]] established by [[Louis Riel]] during the [[Red River Rebellion]] of 1869 – 1870. He graduated with honours from the [[University of Toronto]] in 1857. He also received a Master of Arts from the same university later in 1865. He was the [[Métis in Canada|Métis]] son of Scottish immigrant author and [[Hudson's Bay Company]] fur trader/administrator [[Alexander Ross (fur trader)|Alexander Ross]] and Sarah (Timentwa),an Okanagan tribal woman. James married Margaret Smith in Toronto on 18 May 1858.<ref>http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/ross_james_1835_71_10E.html</ref>
Ross represented the views of the [[English Canadian|anglophone]] community in the [[Red River Colony]], defusing tensions between the [[French language|French]]- and [[English language|English]]-speaking delegates of the [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis]] National Committee. He served on the Convention of Forty<ref>http://www.metismuseum.ca/media/document.php/12539.Convention%20of%20Forty%20revised.pdf</ref> (January 25, 1870 to February 10, 1870) as a representative of St. John's Parish. Ross served as translator of the speeches of the French delegates, and also served on the "Committee of Six" responsible for drafting the "List of Rights" that were presented to the [[Government of Canada]] during the negotiations that led to the [[Manitoba Act]] of 1870 and the entry of the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] of [[Manitoba]] into the [[Canadian Confederation]]. <ref>http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/ross_james_1835_71_10E.html</ref>James Ross died of tuberculosis on September 20, 1871.
== External links == * [http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=5241 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online''] * [http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/people/ross_j.shtml Memorable Manitobans: James Ross (1835-1871)] * [https://mspace.lib.umanitoba.ca/handle/1993/3469 James Ross : 1835-1871 : the life and times of an English-speaking halfbreed in the old Red River settlement; Remis, Leonard Lawrence]

{{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox military person | name = The Earl of Ypres | image = John French, 1st Earl of Ypres, Bain photo portrait, seated, cropped.jpg | image_size = 225px | caption = Field Marshal The Earl of Ypres | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1852|09|28|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Ripple, Kent|Ripple]], [[Kent]], England | death_date = {{Death date and age|1925|05|22|1852|09|28|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Deal, Kent|Deal]], [[Kent]], England | placeofburial = Ripple, Kent | allegiance = United Kingdom | branch = [[Royal Navy]] (1866–70)
[[British Army]] (1870–1921) | serviceyears = 1866–1921 | rank = [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] | unit = [[8th King's Royal Irish Hussars]]
[[19th Royal Hussars]] | commands = {{Plain list| * [[Commander-in-Chief, Home Forces]] * [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]] * [[Chief of the General Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Imperial General Staff]] * [[Aldershot Command]] * [[I Corps (United Kingdom)|1st Army Corps]] }} | battles = {{Plain list| * [[Mahdist War]] * [[Second Boer War]] * [[First World War]] * [[Irish War of Independence]] }} | awards = {{Plain list| * [[Knight of the Order of St Patrick]] * [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] * [[Member of the Order of Merit]] * [[Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order]] * [[Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] }} | relations = [[Charlotte Despard]] (sister) }} [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] '''John Denton Pinkstone French, 1st Earl of Ypres''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|KP|GCB|OM|GCVO|KCMG|ADC|PC}} (28 September 1852 – 22 May 1925), known as '''Sir John French''' from 1901 to 1916, and as '''The Viscount French''' between 1916 and 1922, was a senior [[British Army]] [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]]. Born in Kent to an [[Anglo-Irish]] family, he saw brief service as a [[midshipman]] in the [[Royal Navy]], before becoming a [[cavalry]] officer. He achieved rapid promotion and distinguished himself on the [[Nile Expedition|Gordon Relief Expedition]]. French had a considerable reputation as a womaniser throughout his life and his career nearly ended when he was cited in the divorce of a brother officer whilst in [[British Raj|India]] in the early 1890s. French became a national hero during the [[Second Boer War]]. He won the [[Battle of Elandslaagte]] near Ladysmith, escaping under fire on the last train as the [[Siege of Ladysmith|siege]] began. He then commanded the Cavalry Division, winning the Battle of Klip Drift during a march to [[Siege of Kimberley|relieve Kimberley]]. He later conducted [[Counter-insurgency]] operations in [[Cape Colony]]. During the Edwardian Period he commanded [[I Corps (United Kingdom)|I Corps]] at [[Aldershot Command|Aldershot]], then served as Inspector-General of the Army, before becoming [[Chief of the General Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Imperial General Staff]] (CIGS, the professional head of the British Army) in 1912. During this time he helped to prepare the British Army for a possible European War, and was also one of those who insisted, in the so-called “cavalry controversy”, that cavalry still be trained to charge with sabre and lance rather than only fighting dismounted with firearms. During the [[Curragh incident]] he had to resign as CIGS after promising [[Hubert Gough]] in writing that the Army would not be used to coerce Ulster Protestants into a [[Home Rule Crisis|Home Rule Ireland]]. French’s most important role was as [[Commander-in-chief|Commander-in-Chief]] (C-in-C) of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]] (BEF) for the first year and a half of the [[World War I|First World War]]. He had an immediate personality clash with the French General [[Charles Lanrezac]]. After the British suffered heavy casualties at the battles of [[Battle of Mons|Mons]] and [[Battle of Le Cateau|Le Cateau]] (where [[Horace Smith-Dorrien|Smith-Dorrien]] made a stand contrary to French's wishes), French wanted to withdraw the BEF from the Allied line to refit and only agreed to take part in the [[First Battle of the Marne]] after a private meeting with the [[Secretary of State for War]], [[Herbert Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]], against whom he bore a grudge thereafter. In May 1915 he leaked information about [[Shell Crisis of 1915|shell shortages]] to the press in the hope of engineering Kitchener’s removal. By summer 1915 French’s command was being increasingly criticised in London by Kitchener and other members of the government, and by [[Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig|Haig]], [[Sir William Robertson, 1st Baronet|Robertson]] and other senior generals in France. After the [[Battle of Loos]], at which French's slow release of [[XI Corps (United Kingdom)|XI Corps]] from reserve was blamed for the failure to achieve a decisive breakthrough on the first day, [[H. H. Asquith]], the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]], demanded his resignation. Haig, who was formerly French's trusted subordinate and who had saved him from bankruptcy by lending him a large sum of money in 1899, replaced him. French was then appointed [[Commander-in-Chief, Home Forces]] for 1916–18. This period saw the country running increasingly short of manpower for the Army. Whilst the [[Battle of Passchendaele|Third Battle of Ypres]] was in progress, French, as part of [[David Lloyd George|Lloyd George]]’s manoeuvres to reduce the power of Haig and Robertson, submitted a paper which was critical of Haig's command record and which recommended that there be no further major [[Offensive (military)|offensive]]s until the [[American Expeditionary Forces|American Expeditionary Force]] (AEF) was present in strength. He then became [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland]] in 1918, a position he held throughout much of the [[Irish War of Independence]] (1919–1922), in which his own sister was involved on the republican side. During this time he published ''1914'', an inaccurate and much criticised volume of memoirs. {{TOC limit|3}} ==Early life and career== ===Family=== French's family was related to the [[Baron de Freyne|French/De Freyne family]] which had gone to [[County Wexford|Wexford]] in the fourteenth century and had substantial estates at Frenchpark, [[County Roscommon|Roscommon]]. French always regarded himself as "Irish", although his branch of the family had lived in England since the eighteenth century.Heathcote, p. 130{{cite web|url=http://www.frenchfamilyassoc.com/FFA/CHARTSWEB/IREFa.htm|title=French Family of Frenchpark, and Cloonshanville Priory|publisher=French Family Association|accessdate=14 May 2013}}Holmes 2004, p. 15 His father was Commander John Tracey William French, [[Royal Navy|RN]], of Ripple Vale in Kent (born 1808, died 1854), who had fought at [[Battle of Navarino|Navarino]] and under [[Charles Napier (Royal Navy officer)|Napier]] in support of [[Pedro I of Brazil|Dom Pedro]] in the [[Liberal Wars|Portuguese Civil War]]. His mother was Margaret Eccles from [[Glasgow]], who, after suffering a breakdown after her husband's death, was eventually institutionalised after being diagnosed as insane.Cassar 1985, p. 19 She died in 1867, leaving French to be brought up by his sisters.Bond & Cave 2009, p. 52{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/33272?docPos=3|title=John French, 1st Earl of Ypres|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=5 February 2012}} He was educated at a [[Harrow, London|Harrow]] preparatory school and [[Eastman's Royal Naval Academy]] at [[Portsmouth]] before joining the [[Royal Navy]] in 1866.{{cite web|url=http://www.kcl.ac.uk/lhcma/locreg/FRENCH.shtml|title=FRENCH, Sir John Denton Pinkstone, (1852–1925), 1st Earl of Ypres, Field Marshal|publisher=Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives|accessdate=5 February 2012}} ===Royal Navy=== He joined the Royal Navy because it gave him a chance to leave home four or five years earlier than the Army. From August 1866 he trained on board the three-decker battleship [[HMS Britannia (1820)|HMS ''Britannia'']] at Dartmouth. He obtained only an "average" certificate, which required him to do a further six months training on board another ship—the frigate [[HMS Bristol (1861)|HMS ''Bristol'']] at Sheerness from January 1868—before qualifying as a midshipman.Holmes 2004, pp. 17–19 In 1869, he served as a midshipman on [[HMS Warrior (1860)|HMS ''Warrior'']], commanded by Captain Boys, an old friend of French's father. She patrolled in the [[English Channel]] and off Spain and Portugal. While in [[Lisbon]], French was able to hire horses and ride over [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Wellington]]’s old battlefields. During his service, he also witnessed the accidental sinking of [[HMS Captain (1869)|HMS ''Captain'']]. He resigned from the Royal Navy in November 1870, as he was discovered to be [[Acrophobia|acrophobic]]Wells, p. 148 and to suffer from seasickness.Reid 2006, p. 61 ===Early army career=== French joined the [[West Suffolk Militia|Suffolk Artillery Militia]] in November 1870,{{London Gazette|issue=24069|page=888|date=27 February 1874}} where he was expected to put in about two months a year with the regiment. He initially failed his exams (mathematics and foreign languages) for a regular commission, and had to hire a new tutor, losing the fees he had paid in advance to the previous one.Holmes 2004, pp. 20–22 He was commissioned as a lieutenant in the [[8th King's Royal Irish Hussars]] on 28 February 1874, a prestigious regiment whose officers often drank [[claret]] for breakfast, but there is no evidence that he ever served with them. He transferred to the [[19th Hussars]] on 11 March 1874,{{London Gazette|issue=24074|page=1591|date=10 March 1874|nolink=y}} possibly as it was cheaper—following the sale of the family home at Ripple Valley French’s private income of £1,000 per annum was enough to cover the £500–£600 required by his new regiment.
